Description: Optimization problem where the objective function and constraints are linear. Very well-studied and efficient solvers exist.
LP with the added constraint that some or all variables must be integers. Significantly harder than LP.
Solvability: NP-hard (can be very difficult to solve)

Description: Combination of LP and IP - some variables are continuous, some are integer.
Optimization problem where either the objective function or at least one constraint is nonlinear.

Abbreviation: Problems where the objective function and feasible region are convex. Guarantee global optima.
Description: Generally solvable in polynomial time (with specialized solvers)
Breaking down a complex problem into smaller, overlapping subproblems, solving each subproblem only once, and storing the solutions to avoid redundant computation.
Example: but can suffer from the curse of dimensionality

Description: Finding an optimal object from a finite set of objects. Often involves permutations, combinations, and graphs.
LP with a quadratic objective function. Can be solved efficiently with specialized methods.
Optimization under uncertainty, where some parameters are random variables.
Solvability: Difficult (often requires scenario-based or robust optimization)

Description: Optimization problem involving posynomials (sums of products of variables raised to powers).
Solvability: Generally solvable via transformation to convex problem
